headline: Company okay, but Business Client Services is a mess
pros: Working from home during the pandemic, once you're done with the day that's it.
cons:
Other parts of the business are okay, but Business Client Services is a train wreck. Clerks are severely overworked, too many mergers, management refuses to help with the workload or hire more full-time people. Communication is poor. 

Some managers seem to discriminate against African-American employees. One BCS team placed just about all of their African-American team members on corrective action (a step from firing). For African-Americans, I do not recommend.

Some BCS managers micromanage and have no respect for the health of their reports. At the beginning of the pandemic, management tried to keep the team in the office as long as possible as our state surged in Covid cases, and only relented when teammates resisted their push to stay in-office. The managers tried to keep the team from listening to company-wide addresses so we wouldn't know the entire office was going remote. 

Great teammates are leaving left and right because of management's actions.

headline: Unappreciated TCF Slave

TCF has recently merged with Chemical Bank and some weird stuff has been happening since. Like change of schedules, culture, attitudes, etc. They don’t check in with you to see how you are doing, they overwork you and treat you like a slave. It’s always about the errors that you make and not the good you do. I noticed in this department there was favoritism and certain people didn’t have to log in on phones and accept incoming branch or contact center calls because they had a high volume of alerts and they do high volumes of work. Well, everyone else in the department does high volumes of work and they have to take up the slack of other people. It really wasn’t fair. And about breaks, you have a choice because of the volume of work and you feel forced into it... You take your 15 minute break, take your lunch and fall behind and stay late OR skip your breaks and work unpaid during lunch and stay a little late. If you enjoy slavery and working so much without a break this is the department for you!! And recently, they want to change your schedules for you to work 11-8 and force a one hour lunch on you so they can have coverage. In this department you verify checks and harass banks and the maker and if you enjoy harassing people this job is for you. They also hold cash deposited into the atm until they “verify” it and that is a negative customer impact. And i feel this department is also incompetent when it comes to claims. I’ve had a branch call to check up on a claim and i asked person working on it what the status was and apparently they were on lunch, the branch personnel then yells at me and says you all have been on lunch for a long time. Then i send their information and forward it to the people working on it and they never reach out and I’m the one getting yelled at once again because of other peoples incompetence . Outside of everything that goes on in this department, it’s a negative workplace. People angrily drive into the parking lot, throw doors open in your face and act pushy in the confidence areas and they have no picnics for employees unless you pay to go and the cafeteria upstairs at the Plymouth is expensive and mediocre.

headline: Relationship Banker
pros:
*Full time positions available

*No experience necessary, apart from cash handling experience

*Incentives

*Low impact work - run deposit, transfer, withdrawal transactions - cross sell to current and new customers - open new accounts

*Social coworkers
cons:
*Nearly paid minimum wage for work that's evaluated at 12-14/hr at other banks. Even lower management agrees that TCF Bank is one of the lowest paying banks out there.

*incentive is tied to team performance, not the worst con out there, but not a fun one

*heavily sales oriented. Virtually every customer needs to be cross sold to manage reaching sales goal. If you don't make your sales goal for two months straight. You're put on an action plan. If you don't make your sales 2 months after that, you're let go. This is dependant on your manager and district manager. You need to sell 70 checking or savings account, 21 CDs or credit cards, or 42 cross sells. Or a mix. Essentially, you need 2-3 mixed accounts every day you work to make sure you stay on track. It's challenging since the vast majority of your clientele are repeats. They've heard the sales pitch countless of times. 

*TCF free checking isn't actually free. Our district /regional manager forces locations to sell a checking account with a book of checks. They're roughly 20. If you don't keep a rate of 95+%, you get in trouble. We're not allowed to sell a checking account with checks. They only way we're able to is if the customer makes a fuss and we then have to get the managers approval or the district /regional manager Ralph if your store manager isn't available. 

*Jewel locations are tiny. If you work at a bad jewels, the location can get very hot since jewels won't fix the vents near the tcf branch. Since we have to share the break room with jewels, its really disgusting and depressing. Not what you would expect from working at a bank. Bathrooms are gross.

*high turnover

*accounts are open at 90% regulation standards. We try to follow the rules 100%, but sometimes we let a few things slide. We don't explain everything, we don't give all the pamphlets. We have to juggle transactions and account openings 

*the business day cutoff is at 2pm. It's meant to maximize overdraft fees. Disgusting. When I learned this, me and manager got a bit into an argument. 

*Insurance is not worth it, especially considering it's a bank.

headline: Needs culture and benefits improvement
pros: Mid-size bank with multiple lines of business where employees can see different industries. The company is starting to invest in technology and improving the physical workplace environment. There appears to be an initiative by Sr. Management to make the company more attractive to younger professionals as there have been surveys and organized meetings for millennials to talk about pros and cons and provide feedback on areas they feel are important.
cons:
There are significant cultural differences between the divisions at TCF. Some have excellent reputations and attract current employees to fill open positions, others have poor reputations and typically have to hire externally to fill roles. I find the culture very old fashion in my division, where there is very little flexibility by management on working from home or adjusting an individuals daily work schedule (i.e. starting earlier to leave earlier). 

Compensation is okay, I received an increase in base salary when I came to TCF, however the benefits package is poor in my opinion. The 401k match doesn't start until you've had your 1 year anniversary, and has a 5 year vesting period on the match. The only health insurance option is a high deductible plan with an HSA, and the dental insurance is 100% paid by the employee. There is no maternity leave offered, which I feel is a big negative. With the other large employers in Minneapolis (General Mills, Target, US Bank, etc) the competition for the best talent is strong, and TCF's benefit package falls significantly short.  Not having a match on my 401k for the first year, as well as the additional out of pocket costs on the health and dental insurance almost completely offset the increase in salary I received coming to TCF. I know, my fault for not doing enough research, but I was and still am very disappointed.

We also go through more paper than any other company I've ever worked for, I personally believe this is a waste with the technology available today.

headline: Good learning experience, but better opportunities elsewhere.
pros:
-You get some great experience in the banking world right off the bat. You will do much more than tellers do at other banks and overall you will learn A TON about banking and sales.

-The bank is a small regional bank. So you really do feel like part of a big family and since team members frequently leave to go to other branches you have the ability to network and know whats going on company wide.

-More of a casual environment than a lot of other banks.

-William Cooper seems to be a pretty decent guy.

-Lots of opportunity to volunteer and do good things in the communities in Colorado.

-Easy to get promoted to supervisor and put management experience on your resume.
cons:
- Some in the company think that outside sales(knocking on random businesses), telemarketing, and setting up tables at flea markets and other events is an effective and profitable endeavor, and it's not.

-Bank is known as a second chance bank and has a terrible reputation and brand image in Colorado.

-Noncompetitive products in a competitive market. The bank is too big to provide a credit union experience and not big enough to be able to offer half of what wells fargo and chase do. 

-Branch Team members have so many responsibilities that they are most often jacks of all trades and masters of none. Very few have the in depth knowledge needed to do all aspects of their job well. This is also due to a very poor training program.

-Terrible technology. Simple task that are easy at other banks are a nightmare because TCF has old outdated and user unfriendly technology.

-Lack of cohesion among all the different departments and offices. Maybe it's better in Minnesota.

-Lack of quality upper management leads to misguided vision for the company and a lack of any clear sensible way to take the company in a better direction.

-Pay is non competitive for the work that you will be doing. Other banks pay better for less responsibility.

-Lack of oppertunities. The bank is small and there is no room to move past supervisor, unless your willing to spend a long time making next to nothing to get there.

headline: My Horrible Experience As A TCF Bank Customer Service Representative At What Had To Be The Worst Branch It Had
pros: Working at that branch in particular gives you a great opportunity to meet a vast  variety of people. That community runs at a very fast pace, and if you are one for liveliness and excitement, then that branch is most definitely the place for you.
cons: From the first day that I went into that branch, there was rudeness and an overwhelming cattiness from the employees, including the supervisors that no one would believe! No one wants to work in such a place of unprofessionalism.  Everything that you are taught in training just went out of the window. No one followed proper security procedures for the atm check or the vault count.  I hated being at that branch.  The manager already had her favorite customer service representatives established. She let them do and act however they chose.  There was so much stealing of the money by the supervisors going on at that time that at least three of the supervisors were fired for suspicious activities while I was there.  The replacements that were sent to the branch were only better in the fact that they weren't blatantly stealing the money from the vault or making bogus transactions like the others did.  But what they did do, is speak to  the employees in a very undermining manner.  There was no mutual respect for everyone as you would expect the workplace to be.  I lasted for quite a while to my surprise, because I'm not a quitter. But eventually, I ended up leaving when I found something else much more suitable.  Let me say that the supervisors seemed to not like me because I demanded respect (and gave it as well.)

cons: There was no chance for advancement. The turn around rate is extremely high, more or less feels like, get the new blood in there, have them bring all their friends and family, then let them go to keep the accounts.

headline: Not Enough
pros: easy, advancement, growth, hours, location
cons: old fashioned, boring, slow paced, repetitive, technologically disadvantaged, angry customers, policies

headline: One of the worse employers out there!
pros: Very little but can help you be more open to sales and get your foot in the door for a banking career.
cons: TCF bank thrives only on sales and does not care about the customers at all. They want the employees to meet ridiculous almost impossible sales and if you don't meet them you can get fired. Also while I was employed with them, there was a change in management 4 times and I only worked 6 months with the company. Almost each time a new manager came someone got fired or they would contradict whatever the previous manager taught you. They also over worked the employees expecting them to be bankers, tellers, and sales associates when they pay you low salaries.

headline: good first job out of college
pros:
-sales experience, very sales oriented. when i started, i didn't like the banking aspect of the job, but now that i just focus on the sales aspect its a lot more enjoyable. 
-ok career advancement
-flexible scheduling
-bonuses when you are a supervisor are great. you get personal and branch bonuses. even though I made 12.02, Ive bonused the last five months and it can equal to about 14 an hour
-three weeks vacation time per year
cons:
-people who don't work with people think they know people. Our regional manager would have us making sales calls on sunday mornings to former and existing customers. corporate came in and took down all inviting aspects of our branch away. We have customers who come in and say how uninviting it is now and ask if we are closing (this happens on a daily basis) 
-company is constantly changing, its hard to ever actually learn policies and procedures. (TCF stands for things change frequently!) 
-I've worked here for a year and have had a new branch manager every four months
-corporate politics
-switch over at 3 can confuse customers and sometimes cause problems with new customers

headline: I learned a great deal while working at TCF Bank.
pros: You learn a lot.  You learn how to sell different products and services to existing and potential clients, you learn how to speak politely and professionally with your colleagues as well as clients, you learn how the banking system works and you learn to manage your time and keep up to date with policy changes, etc...
cons: Sometimes you are micro-managed which can become annoying and disrupt you from doing what you do best without someone looking over your shoulder all the time.  I think that they should receive some extra PTO.

headline: Working for Tcf Bank you always have to be ready for change
pros: Tcf bank has some nice place to work with
cons: Things changed FREQUENTLY is what Tcf stand for

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Great place to work and build your career. Management very supportive! Great company culture and fantastic employees! Enjoying working here everyday, would recommend this as great career place! Never been happier with an employer. TCF does try to promote within and gives everyone a fair chance to do great. Very professional atmosphere everywhere in a company and great rewards and bonuses!
cons: Really don`t have any cons personally, love my job :)

headline: COMPANY SUCKS
pros: Women at least can kinda wear whatever, as long as its work pants and no logo shirts. As long as you have a good staff, work environment is fun.
cons: All the company cares for are sales. The pay sucks, only a quarter raise once a year even if you make your sales for the year. And hours suck.

headline: Good start
pros: Very good start if you decided to pick 'Banking' for your future carrier, Good training and many challenges at work if you are a supervisor basically you run most of the operations at the branch! plus you do teller, management, and personal work at once ! so you will be a pro after 1 year
cons:
Online banking interface is very old and confusing, Mobile app is very limited and no phone check deposit, plus the bank is very conservative when it comes to step up and facing the new technology challenges like other bank are moving fast forward. 
I have many notes as CONS but its all about the higher ops not branch level ops. I think TCF having a financial difficulties or the hiring the wrong people (higher ops)

headline: TCF= Things Change Frequently but good company
pros: Great opportunities for those who do well with sales goals. I so far have enjoyed many promotions getting moved to Assistant Branch Manager coming here in the next month. For the most part every branch that I've worked at has had great employees with good management for the most part. Sales is a huge focus you hit goals here you get noticed. As of right now everyone is on a point system in terms of checking saving and online statements. The products are competitive with the bigger banks but with a better checking account.
cons: Like I said sales is a BIG part here. Don't get me wrong you can advance with being good at just the operations side but from what I've seen it takes a lot longer. New hires are frequently asked to go on "outside sales" which pretty much means going door to door or setting up tables at places to offer people checking and savings accounts. Also management meaning upper management Regional Manager and Director change sales on almost a monthly basis. One month you can do outside sales, the next you can't after that maybe just table events. When a decision is made it very rarely is law for more than a quarter. It's almost comical how often rules change as far as sales goes.

headline: Supervsior
pros: promotion, good pay, PTO, company values your opinion
cons: sales goals, not everyone follows the same rules as other branches

headline: Great place for individuals to gain experience and grow within a company.
pros: The pros with this bank is that advancement opportunities are offered all the time. Also great place to gain skills for future career advancement, new job, etc.
cons: Unfortunately some individuals that are working for the company don't understand the difference of customer preferences from 10 years to now. Also direction is very vague within the company. They first say one thing and a few days later they decide to change their mind. Confusion is always a must at busy branches. Unfortunately many employees leave the company due to changes within the company, low pay, and in some situations management.

headline: Messed up! Not even a one star! more like half a star but I wasn't given the option
pros: The experience so that you can go to a better job that does NOT force you to open an account and does not punish you if you don't. It's busy so rude coworkers don't have time to conversate with you. Thank goodness.
cons: Manager forces employees to open accounts cause desperation to reach goal. If not, they decrease ur hours, be rude, send you home. Scheduling manager said and I quote "I bet you you're not gonna get any hours" walks away....and what a coincidence I got sent home today....they very much dislike entry level employees because we are new and still has a lot to learn and we are not pros. They must've forgotten they were once just like us.

headline: Great Place to Learn and Grow
pros: Great training program for new hires, flexible hours and schedule, professional yet personal atmosphere and approach to customer service, advancement opportunities.
cons: Salary ranges are low compared to competitors in the industry.

headline: Great Opportunities
pros: Great opportunities for advancement. Mature corporate culture. Stable company with conservative financial values. Beginning to invest more in information technology and new products.
cons: Slow to the game with new products. Lower than average salaries for many employees. I was significantly underpaid for several years, but now believe that my loyalty has paid off substantially. Tellers and lower-level employees fare much worse.

headline: Don't bother
pros: The team I had was wonderful and dedicated. The tried to be very conscious if the work flow and the others on the team
cons: Micro management, do I need to say more? All they wanted was to micro manage and not ask what was a good idea or a bad one

headline: Rewarding
pros:
-Good way to get into banking
-Easy to get promoted
-Incentives are nice
cons:
-99% sales driven job
-Team must be good to get any incentives 
-Constant change in tellers/managers

headline: An all inclusive company to work for.
pros: Hires, trains and promotes minorities and women at a greater percentage than all other institutions. Makes a concerted effort to empower people the other financial institutions have historically ignored  due to systemic institutional corporate racism.
cons: Base pay slightly below par, however , incentive pay scales are above  other institutions. Needs to get rid of bad apples whom lack the intellectual gray matter necessary to take TCF to the next level with regard to customer service.

headline: horrible bank does not value their employees
pros: u get paid training, the experience is grand if you take charge.
cons: horrible when it comes to the pay. They only hire to get accounts.if you're not getting account they will fire you. I got no bonuses for opening the accounts. They tell you after 6 months you have a chance for advancement, this is a lie. They have a bad reputation for taking people's money so it's very hard to open account, they deduct your hours and give you write ups that eventually result in you being fired. This job is a good entry level job but it's a joke if you want to be taken serious. They don't care about your work ethic they just want to see accounthis job is good if you're good at selling don't waste your time if you don't like being pushed to sell everyday

headline: MANAGER
pros: Nothing good, been with the company for 4 years, did not learn or gain anything
cons: I suggest not to work there

headline: worst place I've ever worked
pros: I had some great colleagues
cons: worst manager I've ever had;  "old boys" club; archaic technology; assumes the worst in everyone.  set up for failure, not development

headline: Not the best
pros: Pay raises every three months, Training for advancement opportunities, Opportunities for incentives,Great opportunity to gain some banking experience
cons:
Popularity contest
System Outages
Hours- Weekends & Holidays
Not much room for advancement
Wages are not very competitive
Only offers part time teller positions

headline: TCF thorws numerous curve balls to make you eventually fail.
pros: A very fast pace environment with fast career growth opportunities.
cons: TCF is heavily focused on getting accounts but then when you do you become investigated for it.

headline: My experience with TCF was one of the worst in my career
pros:
On a cross functional basis, the people I worked with were great. 
They are currently offering above market title, salary and bonus pay.
cons: No HR processes/practices, no personal growth, no training.

headline: Great Place
pros: Lots of learning. great pay
cons: nothing much to mention

headline: Declining Every Month
pros:
-Hours are very flexible and many hours to be given out since open on Saturdays and Sundays
-You can move up quickly if you are decent at your job
cons:
-Employees are underpaid a lot
-Unethical practices are taught to employees to use on customers
-Very much of a double standard bank
-Do not care about their employees in the slightest
-Very big turn around, they even tell you that in your training
-Every branch has a different way of doing things and executing the policies, no two branches are alike

headline: Okay
pros: Good starting job, flexible hours
cons: Compensation was terrible, company did not value its employee's

headline: Pleasant
pros: Knowledge, experience, money, meeting people, Networking
cons: In Store, hours, Holidays, Cramped quarters, too small

headline: Short term company with short term goals.
pros: you really don't need much to get a joh as a teller at this bank, i had not even finished high school yet. pay was good for my age but compared to there competation its not much. group performance bonuses
cons: Sales are all they care about, even if you are a good teller you are judged on how many accounts you open, weather there profitable or not. people will try and steal your sales, even your managers will. this will happen especially early in your time, when you don't know whats happening.

headline: TCF is a challenging yet very rewarding company to work for.
pros:
The people here are for the most part - phenominal.
There is a very strong work ethic and attainable goals.
cons: There can be a diconnect between departments, causing customer service to be affected.  It also makes it difficult to perform many of the duties asked of you in an efficient manner while providing correct information.

headline: Teller 2.
pros: Management sticks together . Easy to get in. My corporate trainers were awesome.
cons: Too many write ups, managers are not indepedent thinkers, low pay.

headline: Great depending on your manager.
pros: promotion opportunities, gain customer service experience
cons: inconsistency in leadership from branch to branch, outdated policies, "who you know not what you know" type of company, favoritism based on years with company, unethical  employees, frequent changes, too goal oriented, low pay compared to other banks

headline: Not a bad place to gain some experience.
pros: You will gain experience dealing with unhappy customers. Growth to a certain level is very attainable. Most of the people in the company are young.
cons: Unhappy customers because of incompetent employees that are out of your control. Checking account focused, not money focused. It is more of "who you know". Free thinking is not allowed.

headline: Good intro job, but try to move on quickly.
pros: Great at promoting from within and good entry level job if you're going into finance.
cons: TCF does not care about its employees.  The pay is very poor and incentives are minimal.  You also feel left behind due to their snail's pace when it comes to advances in banking.  i.e. mobile and online banking

headline: Ok place to work.
pros: Learned different technologies and work shift.
cons: Terrible Leadership.   Learn some empathy and respect.

headline: Not a place you want to stay
pros: I was a teller at TCF Bank while transitioning from High School to college. My managers were actually very good people, which made work enjoyable.
cons: Pay is fairly low, with no real chance for career advancement. Sadly, Many of the workers there are college grads with meaningless degrees, or simply complete fools trying to scrape by in life.

headline: Branch supervisor
pros: great opportunities to move up in the company, good people, usually not to hard to get a full time position, works with ur school hours, good banking experience
cons: too much stress for low pay, TCF = the customer is F*<ked, old system, no bright future in staying with the company, if your good at sales they will milk you for accounts, very routine and boring at times

headline: TCF is a decent place to work, but there is quite a bit of turnaround at the Colorado branches.
pros: Coworkers were always friendly and helpful, especially after I finished the two week training. Since branch staff is small, we got to be kind of like a little family!
cons: Training was two weeks long but I feel that it didn't really prepare me for the branch as well as it probably should have. Selling accounts is required, but very difficult.

headline: Fun position and team to work with, good first job, shady company, crappy software and databases
pros: I had a great team and a great branch manager, most employees were young or getting a first job out of high school, I thought the day to day tasks were fun and easy, great job to gain skills, my branch manager was flexible with finding hours for everyone, my branch was a positive place to work with very little drama, I would go back if the pay was higher.
cons: High stress, angry customers, confused and under trained employees, software sucked, bad computers and database systems, we were robbed too many times, pushed really hard to open accounts (small bonuses), training was too short, pay sucks (other banks pay 2 to 3 dollars more per hour), the customer's get screwed a lot

headline: Awful, awful.
pros:
-Flexible work schedule
- Good entry level to banking
cons:
- Management is literally stuck-up and not educated about managing or banking
- Half of the people do all the work while the rest sit around and do nothing.
- Pay is not worth the headaches.

headline: Leave as soon as you can
pros: Flexible schedule they will hire you with no experience and my old manager liked to promote with in. That's about it
cons: They only good manager they had they get rid of for a bogus reason she gets hurt on company time and she gets fired after she's off medical. She was the best manager I ever worked for and the only reason I am still at Tcf. I will be gone as soon as I can be

headline: Good experience. Bad upper management.
pros: Work here if you want some good experience. Pay is decent but still low compared to other teller jobs. TCF is a good stepping stone if you want to eventually work at a different bank.
cons: If you don't meet sales quotas you will be fired or seriously reprimanded. There is often very high workload with very little recognition.

headline: A Decent Company, but Too Many Changes
pros: Fun co-workers, easy to get to, plenty of surrounding attractions
cons: Constant changes (the centralized location is moving to Plymouth, transplanting over 1,500, I have no way to actually get there, so I'll be out of a job soon), terrible pay compared to other banks for the same job ($13 vs $17-$19 is crazy)

headline: Great starting environment to gain experience in the banking sector and positive environment.
pros: I really enjoy the staff I have and the environment I have been surrounded by. The company is really looking to be heading to the right direction at a good pace. I heard from higher management our company is working daily on catching up with bigger banks on technology and methods to keep us relevant with consumers. It is great to build your starting career in banking as they really do not require much when I started as a teller. Typical bank, but much better atmosphere with better personality for sure.
cons: The pay is now where near as good as other banks. I compare our salaries to other banks and we are getting ripped off which is the real reason this place is not perfect. Branch managers seem to not be licensed on a lot of things anymore which is disappointing for anyone looking to be a branch manager cause that means less pay when you try to climb the ladder. Everything is a branch goal usually and tellers do not get any well paid incentive.

headline: Customer Service- Call Center
pros: Pay was decent, no selling
cons: Bad training, barely saw supervisor unless you did something wrong, awful work hours

headline: Good place to start in the banking industry
pros:
Coworkers 
Ability to be promoted 
Easy to get full time
cons:
Bad pay 
Poor raises 
Terrible sales/incentive programs

headline: Good experience for an entry-level position
pros: Good experience for an entry-level job in the commercial banking industry with other employees always willing to lend a hand.  As an entry-level job, you learn a ton about the underwriting process and are able to choose what career path you'd like to take (career underwriter, lender, management), assuming you want to stay in the banking industry.
cons: High turnover with this position and the bank doesn't seem to care.  The pay isn't great and after a few years in this position many people go elsewhere for more money.  There is no actual "training" for this position.  You're thrown into the job running, which can be good or a bit intimidating for some.  Additionally, it's hard to get management to pinpoint dates for promotion.

headline: IT was okay...
pros: Compensation, good hours, & great co-workers
cons: Cared more about #'s then customer attainment

headline: Out of Touch
pros: Their incentive contests were a nice way to compensate high performers.  Leadership at the highest level is solid.  Provides a results-based atmosphere for employees without college education.
cons: Out-dated technology, constant change, poor retail product decisions, low compensation.  TCF tried to stabilize and grow earnings by decreasing costs, not by increasing and diversifying revenues.

headline: In the beginning i loved my job... towards the end i could not wait to leave!
pros: co-workers were great, made some amazing friends.
cons: Too focused on sales i.e. no customer service. My branch would do just about anything for accounts. Making relationships with other companies was a big part of the job. And if you tried to make a relationship and were unsuccessful you were made to feel terrible.  Colorado just re sized their management. Meaning there is now 1 manager for every 2 branches. Which to me is just absurd!!  With all the responsibilities i had i should have been making much more than i did. Run teller transactions, open and close accounts, answer any and all customer questions, change customer information, file claims for fraud, try and explain the ridiculous fee policies. And the list really does go on.  Also if your not into kissing butt i suggest you have no intentions of moving up. I saw someone receive a write up then not a month later get a promotion. So its all about whos good side you can get on. And don't even think about getting on your Branch manager or even asst. managers bad side. I didn't complete a list complied of leads to get accounts and my hours were cut from 35 to 15.

headline: Good
pros: on going training and growth potenial.
cons: Limited positions within regions divisions.

headline: TCF Bank does a poor job or employee retention
pros: There really are no reasons to work here.  Trust me, I know.  It was always embarrassing to tell others I worked there.
cons: Management; pay; requirement(s) for most jobs only require a high school diploma.  This way, TCF doesn't have to pay so much.

headline: Exceptional Executive Management staff
pros: Salary, support from upper management
cons: Higher expectations to achieve in a small vertical market.

headline: Great Experience
pros: Really do promote within, great team atmosphere not super sales driven like most banks are nowadays
cons: Really low wages, not very competitive at any position but extremely low for what the starting wagers are for tellers at other banks

headline: good place to learn
pros: good hours, learnt a lot about banking.
cons:
pressure to get accounts
walking in the aisle all day long

headline: Horrible I hated working here
pros: The hours are pretty consistent.
cons: The locations you sell at are ridiculous who in their right mind wants to give a random stranger your social security at a ghetto gas station for an account! There's no open door policy if you bring up anything they will belittle you and tell you you're opinion doesn't matter. Regional managers won't speak to you either about issues involving your branch so you're left on your own, better off quitting and finding a better job!  TCF Bank pays is so mediocre so of course turnover is high. If you want to move up there's no point since your pay will be the same as a beginning teller at another bank.

headline: Decent company to work for
pros: Promote from within the company
cons: Hire tellers with no experience

headline: SALES OR NO JOB
pros: meet great people. learn how to sell
cons: to many management changes. when new manager starts they sometimes clean house for no reason

headline: I hated TCF as a workplace and a regular bank.
pros: Decent pay. Okay co-workers Life/work balance is good.
cons: Managers have favorites. Hard sales. I was sexually harassed and the company did NOTHING to assist me and they didn't even fire the guy who did. TCF Bank make you feel like sharks when it comes to sales. Customer service is totally avoided.

headline: okay job...just get experience and leave
pros: When you are young the people you work with are great...Though if you could see some of the absolute idiots that work in this bank then you would think twice about bringing your business here.
cons: Being used by upper management.  The sales goals in my experience are unrealistic unless you cheat.  The regional managers are also just a clueless as how to run a bank.

headline: The worst technology in banking
pros: That the mid leadership are idiots and easily pacified.
cons: The technology is so outdated that it is next to impossible to provide anytype of customer service what so ever.

headline: My experience at TCF was sub-standard for an entry level position.
pros: I had one great supervisor who has since moved on, initial training was thorough, and it was a good place to get practice for a better banking position.
cons: The branch manager did not know how to run the bank, teller transactions were too involved which included sending out card - change of address - problem resolution - and many other tasks which other banks require their managers to do, transactions led to longer lines and unsatisfied clientele.

headline: It's a great place to get experience. But there's too much drama and the sales goals are unrealistic
pros: Good banking, meet great people, customer service, convenience, hours. Being able to move up in the company fast and getting experience
cons: Sales goals are very hard to meet. Too much pressure on sales not actual bank. Drama between branches is annoying.

headline: Great place to start career in banking
pros: A lot of internal promotions and opportunities to move up. Great coworkers.
cons: Open Sundays and many holidays. Very sales driven, little focus on keeping current customers satisfied.

headline: Worked here for 5+ Years, Underpaid until you get to BM Level then its ok.
pros: Customers, Co-Workers, Training, Products, Meetings & Outings
cons: Hours, Holidays, $25 Visa Gift Card "Holiday Bonus", Lack of Empathy, Spends money in the wrong places which end result closes office doors for good.

headline: Tcf bank doesn't care about their employees or customers at the end of the day !
pros: Company trips, incentives, gained knowledge to better myself in my career
cons: Only focused on sales and little employee development. Upper managers are political and take sides with people they 'like'. Tcf pushes employees to open accounts for people that don't really need the relationship. Inconsistency from branch to branch causes chaos.

headline: Very satisfying!
pros: Made long standing relationships. It is like you are with family.
cons: They let me go when they moved the call center to South Dakota.

headline: In the beginning it was fun and exciting, towards the end with a slump in the economy, it became almost hostile.
pros: entry into banking, learn a lot, good opportunity to move into banking, fast pace, promote within
cons: Very aggressive, only thing that matters is numbers, high turnover

headline: If your great at high pressure sales, and not caring about what the customer needs, this job is for you.
pros: Willing to work with my school schedule.
cons: Very uncomfortable, pushy sales. Phone calls from regional manager several times a day pushing to get more accounts. It is ridiculous the things that employees have to do to get accounts- i.e. falsify account info, flirt with customers...we felt pressured into doing anything we had to do to get accounts.

headline: I had a great experience working here.
pros:
Got along with coworkers
got to know customers on first name basis
cons: Horrible pay compared to competition

headline: Low pay high quotas
pros: Generally the other tellers are decent people. Everyone tries their hardest with what's given to them but no mercy when you don't meet your goals
cons: Upper management is a complete mess. No communication between departments/departments getting cut is the norm. The technology is last decade's.

headline: Opportunities are there
pros: Hire from within mentality that allows anyone who is willing to work hard to climb the ladder. Pay is competitive after you are promoted out of entry-level systems.
cons: Generally have lower pay than industry standard, but if that can be mitigated if you are willing and able to advance your position in the company.

headline: Limited growth opportunities, low compensation, good culture
pros: High quality managers and networking in my small corner of TCF. Not all of the company is quite so high quality, however. There is a commitment to development and a competitive benefit plan.
cons: TCF does not compensate employees at the level other banks do. Job opportunities are also severely limited as they laid off half their managers in Colorado and now have one manager for every two branches. Quality managers were asked to take massive pay cuts to assistant manager while inept ones were retained based solely off seniority. There are now a surplus of assistant managers for a very limited number of managers. Promotions have stagnated at every level, as now there are too many assistants so they supervisors can't move up, and the supervisors are stuck so tellers have limited options as well.

headline: Company tried to develop too fast without 1st building their foundation in AZ
pros: flexibility to working hours, not being stuck in same office everyday, loved my managers and co workers.
cons: no guidance, resources were limited when a question came up, no enough marketing of a new bank

headline: It's alright to get some business experience
pros: Advance quickly, a great team working experience
cons: Pay scale is terrible. Crazy customers. No fee reversal

headline: If your not entry level in Career, This is not the place for you.
pros: Great Training opportunities, Likes to promote from Within.
cons:
The Michigan HR Director is a Micro Manager. Appears to be a great resource but will throw you under to protect her over 10 years with Company. 

Company Wages are NOT competitive. Tellers start around 9 dollars while others institutions are 10-12per hour.

headline: TCF
pros: Great company if you are good at sales.  Fast advancement and good management .  I have been here under three years and have advanced to branch manager from a teller
cons: I have been here less than three years and have advanced from a teller to a branch manager with no prior banking experience.  The benefits are horrible since TCF self insures.  Open all holidays except Christmas and open for extended hours in most locations

headline: They only use people no chance to up grade your skills as an employ
pros: Big bank do not care of employees
cons: no chance to move up at all

headline: Great place to work in if you enjoy a strong sales atmosphere.
pros: Great exposure to various customer issues
cons: A very pressured sales environment.

headline: Good learning ground
pros: Flexible working opportunities. It enables every employee to do better for their lives.
cons: Heavy sales focus that is not for everyone. New employees tend to get intimidated. This leads to heavy lifting by the management.

headline: Employees are under valued
pros: flexible scheduling nice co workers
cons: employees not valued, incentive was impossible to get

headline: Awesome
pros: Some of the manager were nice and helpfull.
cons: Some of the things the employees had to achieve

headline: Fine for a College Job
pros: Good hours for a student with varied schedule, usually fun coworkers, looks good on a resume.
cons: Sales goals are unrealistic and constantly pushed, bank policies always changing so it makes for angry customers, such minimal raises that it creates no incentive, disconnected corporate.

headline: Very Professional
pros:
Managers trust employees to make decisions based on their experience and expertise. 
Managemet is conscientous of a work life balance, and are flexible when necessary.
cons:
Extremely conservative culture in terms of adapting to and accepting new and different ideas
Team cohesiveness is lacking in some departments; a small number of individuals often shoulder the bulk of the responsibility

headline: Great co-workers, terrible pay and poor management.
pros:
-Co-workers are great, most become like family.
-Flexible scheduling.
-If you do well with sales, it's fairly easy and quick to move up.
cons:
-Sales is basically the ONLY focus.  If you don't perform to their liking, you're on probation and eventually let go.
-The NSF fees are very difficult to make customers understand, and branch employees are not allowed to reverse fees unless it was due to some sort of bank error.
-Many branch managers are extremely selfish, flaky, and overall bad leaders.  My manager was hardly ever at the branch and never took PTO for the countless weeks she just wouldn't show up.
-The pay is TERRIBLE, especially for the financial industry and for the amount of pressure they put on every employee.
-Coming back to the sales pressure, it's so intense that employees will do nearly anything to make their goals.  An insane amount of employees have been fired for practicing "unethical procedures" in order to try and keep their jobs.  
-There is awful turnover for hourly employees, most tellers are in college just looking for a job to get them buy, and the lower management has to over compensate for their lack of motivation to work and be professional.

headline: Okay pay, crappy job
pros: It's a stable job that isn't going anywhere because TCF is a pretty sizable bank in the state of Minnesota. So if you're interested in getting an entry level banking job it could be worse.

headline: You will move up fast if you screw your customers!!!
pros: The only great thing about being a Branch Manager is that you can make your own schedule. If you decide to be a Branch Manager at TCF Bank, just know that everyone's job has an expiration date on it! Set a plan for yourself to get out like I did! I used TCF just as much as they used me. I went an got an education and reaped the benefits of tuition reimbursement every year to help pay for it. It was easy to go to school since I was in charge of my own schedule. I now have a degree and a career making six figures. Thank you TCF for the title, helped big time on the résumé!
cons:
People get recognized by doing wrong to customers. Many of the top producers will do anything for a a checking account. For example, if someone loses their debit card, many TCF employees tell customers that in order to protect there account and resolve there issue they have to open a new account. In reality, the customer does not need to open a new account, they simply need to cancel the card and order a new one. TCF employees however will persuade the customer otherwise and make the customer believe their account is at risk in order to get a new account sale. If you do not hit your goals you feel a ton of pressure from region managers. I am proud to say I was able to hit my goals legitimately until my last year at TCF. I was good to my customers, but most people are not because of the pressure. This is why I resigned after I got my degree, I refused to lie to customers. TCF does not set its employees up for success. Instead they give unrealistic sales goals that only the best of the shady people can hit! 

The turn over is ridiculously high because they will hire ANYONE! Starting June 2013 they started hiring individuals with no work experience. Who wants someone with handling their money if its there first job? This leave room for more errors. There are so many customers who come in because money is missing from there accounts because of all the processing errors made by these 17 year old employees who are careless. TCF also has no room to be selective in their hiring because they pay less than most banks for the bank teller through assistant manager position.

TCF will ruin is not good for your health, literally!!! All my family and friends say they can tell I am much happier since I resigned. Don't wait time on your life at TCF Bank.... Unless you are good at being dishonest and hurting customers by lying to them, you may fit right in. TCF Bank has a bad reputation which also makes it hard to get legitimate sales. Everyone knows how bad of a bank it is, so when you are out in the aisles talking to customers, they do not even want to give you the time of day. DON'T DO IT!!!

headline: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly.

A lot of employees make stuff up instead of giving out factual information, because they're lazy.

This job tends to be a great starting point for people that may want to get into the banking industry.
cons: FTE is a big issue there. Some branches tend to hire too many people with the little amount of hours that they have available to give out. The sales tends to be a hassle because the pressure on sales can overwhelm employees in the scare of losing their job. Another issue is that a lot of the information is never really taught to you. cons:
The culture at TCF really changed in my five years with the company. They have put more of an emphasis on sales and the bottom line than the customer and their satisfaction. They also have given an unjust favoritism to individuals that work in the branches located in the grocery stores. 
-Advancement based on sales and not any other attributes
- Pay well below the industry average
- Favoritism

headline: Not the best, but not the worst.
pros:
- Management staff is great; we have one of the best branch managers I have ever worked with.  She is amazing and sacrifices so much to see that our branch is operating efficiently.

- Many good products & services offered to customers and employees; free checking AND savings accounts.

- The environment is relatively comfortable when the branch isn't hectic or customers aren't cursing at you.  Some customers are astonishingly courteous and understanding.

- TCF Stock Purchase Plan; investing in an above-average company.
cons:
- Constant changing of company policies & procedures; some may benefit customers, others may hurt customers.  Questionable practices.

- Employees are judged upon how fast they can complete transactions and balance.  Balancing is important, but one shouldn't place an employee in drive-thru every shift just because he/she isn't "Speedy Gonzales" in the front.

- Irate customers that curse profusely, even over little things.  Some are just flat-out rude and could care less about you, but just their money.

- Lackluster technical equipment & devices; stuff breaks down almost all the time and is EXTREMELY annoying.

- Literally impossible to make sales goals by being in the drive-thru; people are in a rush and do not care about another savings account, it seems.

- Too much gossip among staff about the music industry and talk about what is on TV; staff sometimes not prepared with coin or products (money orders, checks) to assist customers.

headline: It's All right for a starter teller position
pros: Promotion's are Easy, Management is very nice to you, and generally the people that you work with are nice as well
cons: I dont like shoving checking accounts down peoples throats, mainly when you dont agree with the policies of the bank anyway

headline: Good place to start.... Then leave
pros: Flexible schedule, good learning experience, benefits, incentive money when sales goals are made, tuition reimbursement
cons: Impossible sales goals, incompetent senior management, horrible products to sell, no room for promotion.

headline: Shallow, cheap, non-loyal employer
pros:
1. Benefits (although they are expensive)
2. The immediate staff are great people to work with
3. Great location
4. In my position I don't have to report to an immediate "in house" supervisor
5. About 2 weeks of paid vacation (includes sick days, total)
cons:
1. Staff are expected to clean the branches. The cleaning crew is paid very little so they do very little
and the staff are expected to clean behind them
2. Marketing and technology is outdated. TCF not willing to venture into new avenues of marketing.
3. Untested procedures and sales pitches. The higher up make up stupid things that the sales staff have to say, which have not been tested and do not provide any positive growth or results
4. All branch music has been turned off to save money
5. Cannot buy trash can liners anymore, to try and save money
6. TCF does not uphold it's promise to employee's for referrals; will promise a referral fee to employee's for business the employee brings in, but TCF higher ups always figure out a way to avoid paying this fee to their employee's
7. They expect you to do over 4 different positions along with your own position and still pay you the least amount of any other bank in the area; they are taking advantage of their employees
8. Bonus structure is constantly re-aligned to keep from paying bonus to their employees
9. Whenever something breaks at the branches, it takes at least 3-6 months to get it fixed
10. Most customers do not like TCF and are rude and mean; yelling at staff and cursing at them. One time someone actually pooped in the sink and another on the floor
11. They do not give raises to those deserving. One employee has been here 9 years and has not received one raise; another was promoted in position but no pay increase
12. Constant negative correspondence from higher ups
13. Constantly changing "the rules" on dress code, procedures, etc...
14. Make staff take silly testing on silly "catch phrases" stressing staff out to study their phrases that have not been tested or proven effective. 
15. The Colorado manager is always changing the rules when policy states something different
16. Procedures are not tested before put into effect. Higher ups just make things up without consulting branch levels on if they work or not.

headline: I was a pleasant experience to work for TCF Bank.

Bank hours

Transactions where easy

People are numbers

Poor customer and employee retention

headline: Great place to work through college and work your way up but needs to invest more in their employees.

headline: Do not even think of applying to this bank

headline: It was alright
pros: Flexible work hours, long lunches, PTO
cons: High rates, low pay, & I got laid off along with 50 other loan officers

headline: Great Start
pros: A great place to start working as a student. Hours aren't too late, plenty of time to do other things after work, weekend shifts to fit in more hours for the week instead of squishing them in during the week. Great environment in most branches, co-workers are always helpful. Offer decent benefit packages for full-time employees. Great place to have on your resume for future career opportunities, or a great place to continue a career.
cons: Pay is not as great compared to other banks. TCF has constant changes to their accounts and not enough options for customers to choose from. Some upper management employees do not care enough about retention, as in taking care of the customers and doing what we need to do to KEEP our current customers. Too much emphasis on opening NEW accounts when the majority of them are not primary accounts. Too much pressure on making goals.

headline: Okay
pros: Flexible schedule, tuition reimbursement, good learning opportunity.   Working in the call center you can wear clothing you are comfortable in.
cons: TCF doesn't have a good reputation and you are under paid in comparison to most other banks.  Growth opportunities are somewhat limited.

headline: Looking for something better
pros:
Great opportunities for advancement. 
Flexible schedule makes this a great place to work while you are going to school. 
Lots of vacation time
cons:
Advancement opportunities beyond Branch Manager are few and far between.
Some Regional Managers are completely incompetent.
Ridiculous sales goals, TCF couldn't care less if you were the worst manager in the world as long as you hit your sales goals. They expect you to sell your soul for a checking account.

headline: Lower pay but great opportunities

headline: first step to get into the banking industry

cons: low pay, and its all about sales, lack of communication between the emplyees and management. hours are not suitable and most of them are in-store.

headline: Good learning retail banking
pros: Training is top of the list for them.
cons: Low income salaries and too much turnover

headline: Overworked
pros: There are not many perks with working with this company. Security is not a top priority, only sales. The best part of this job was getting to know the people.
cons: Low pay scale, small bank trying to imitate big bank sales numbers without the structure or process of how to achieve success. To be told to "grab outside sales accounts" at a bus station or pawn shop is demoralizing and a waste of time and efforts. Sales goals are extremely aggressive, and without a targeted plan for achievement.

headline: Only if you love sales
pros: TCF had a really great training program. The teller trainers really know what they're doing. The training can be kind of intense but my trainer was incredible. There is also a decent incentive program if you can meet their crazy sales requirements. TCF is great if your a terrific sales person. If you work full-time, you do get a vacation time right off the bat and that's nice.
cons:
The stress that comes with this job is ridiculous. There's plenty of room to grow but only if you can reach the monthly sales goal. However, that can be fairly difficult since the bank keeps changing policies making more and more customers unhappy. If you can get in the mindset of the company first, customer second, then you'll be fine. However, it's very difficult. They make it very hard to help your customers and I closed more accounts than opened. 

Also the branch managers never work their assigned hours so if you're the supervisor or assistant manager on duty, be prepared to take the heat. Customers will be very upset and you have no to little tools to help your customers. I worked at two branches and it was the same at both. You speak up against the managers and you will be shown the door.

headline: Could be better
pros: Have had a few personal matters and management has been very kind with allowing time off to attend to personal problems.
cons:
Never recognized for doing work. 
Feel under appreciated.
Does not feel like team environment. Everyone shows up at the start of their shift and leaves right at the time it ends.
Manager does not try to make you feel like part of a team.
Benefits are terrible. Each year premium goes up and services go down.

headline: A job to get a job.
pros: I really enjoyed the customers in the Denver area. I was able to get a lot of good sales experince and meet some very good people with in the company.
cons:
NO PAY! I have over a year in the banking industry before I started and I was still paid very very poorly.

TCF is very behind on technology, only upper management is allowed to have email and all branch reports are printed out then mailed to every branch (I saw a half ream of paper every week for the reports). If anything important needs to be sent to the main office in MN everything must be faxed, this creates lots of errors and makes customers wait. Overall the company is very pro quantity and very much against quality.

headline: It was stressful and not enough pay.
